terrain.surface: Gravel roads through New Mexico desert. Moderate elevation with desert scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local New Mexico event. Desert terrain with remote access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Galactic Grinder is a local event in New Mexico—desert terrain with moderate elevation. The New Mexico desert is scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local New Mexico desert gravel race. Worth it for New Mexico/Southwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to New Mexico—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better New Mexico races: Tour de Los Alamos, Enchanted Circle.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Cedar Hill has very limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Cedar Hill has very limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.ridewithgps_name: Galactic Grinder 53 Mile Orbit Alien Run and Arch with Dutchman Downhill Finish

non_negotiables.why: New Mexico desert requires specific preparation.
New Mexico desert weather is variable.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

topics.weather: Riding in variable New Mexico weather

logistics.explanation: Start times are listed (9:30am for long courses, 9:45am for short), but mandatory GPS navigation requirements suggest course marking is inadequate. Aid stations at miles 23 and 31 for the 37-mile route provide decent support structure.

length.explanation: Three distance options from 12 to 53 miles hit the sweet spot for varied abilities. The 53-mile route with 4,500+ feet of elevation gain delivers serious training stimulus without requiring multi-day recovery. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Multiple sources warn "these roads may be rougher than other gravel event roads" with 12% punchy climbs and 3.8 miles of Alien Run singletrack. Mountain bikes are explicitly welcomed alongside gravel bikes. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 50-mile course delivers 4,500+ feet of climbing through hilly terrain with steep punchy climbs up to 12%. Manageable suffering that tests fitness without destroying recreational riders. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 67°F and lows of 37°F, with a 19% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 33 mph. April in the Four Corners region offers variable conditions. Riders report sections "glazed by traffic and baked under New Mexico sunshine" creating fast-paced hard surfaces mixed with sandy challenging terrain. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting elevation around Cedar Hill sits in the moderate altitude range where flatland riders notice the tax without requiring acclimatization strategy. High enough to matter, not high enough to wreck sea-level athletes. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Racing "three hilly gravel Orbits around Alien Crash Site" through mesas, sandy washes, and singletrack near Aztec Ruins National Monument. Riders describe "some sections of the lunar landscape were sandy and challenging at times."

prestige.explanation: Third annual event pulling 100 riders to Cedar Hill with winners like 19-year-old Logan Lewis and 22-year-old Cobe Freeburn. The "Go Fast, Go Slow, Just Go" philosophy explicitly welcomes all abilities over competitive depth.

race_quality.explanation: Neil Hannum's operation requires mandatory GPS navigation because "there are a bunch of tricky turns out there and we don't want anyone getting lost." Course marking limitations force self-navigation backup systems.

experience.explanation: Race materials emphasize "PLEASE DRESS UP!!!!" for the alien costume tradition and "race through the Aztec Arch in your best intergalactic alien costume." The space theme is taken seriously with multiple costume encouragements.

community.explanation: Part of Aztec Adventures' three-race series with a 20% discount for full participation. Podium finishers range from 10-year-old Cooper Wells to 46-year-old Brent Winebarger, demonstrating the multi-ability welcome.

field_depth.explanation: 100 riders across all distances with cash prizes for open classes. The competitive depth runs from teenage Logan Lewis winning the 50-mile to youth categories, reflecting regional participation over racing talent concentration. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Registration runs $35-65 with three distance options, 4+ miles of singletrack, and cash prizes for podium finishers. The series discount and multiple course lengths deliver solid suffering-per-dollar in unique mesa terrain.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Cedar Hill location requires equipment preparation as organizers warn riders to "make sure your gravel bike is up for the burly roads NM has to offer." Remote Four Corners location means limited lodging and dining infrastructure. Higher total cost than Badlands.

key_takeaways: Race history (founded year, founder if known): Third annual in 2024 (first ~2022); part of Aztec Adventures three-race gravel series; founder Neil Han

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
